items.title: Box dots and default box do not work together as expected in 5.1.0
Dashes in keys
items.body:
Have a JSON data source with a nested key containing dashes. 

Noting that makes for an invalid Python identifier, and "Box will automatically make otherwise inaccessible keys safe to access as an attribute", is there an option to support this format?

```
> j={'custom_fields': {'a_b_c':1, 'd-e-f':2 }}
> j
{'custom_fields': {'a_b_c': 1, 'd-e-f': 2}}

>b = Box(j)
>b.custom_fields.a_b_c
1

> b.custom_fields.d-e-f
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
BoxKeyError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-247-dfed3a13203d> in <module>
----> 1 b.custom_fields.d-e-f

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/box/box.py in __getattr__(self, item)
    484             if self._box_config["default_box"]:
    485                 return self.__get_default(item, attr=True)
--> 486             raise BoxKeyError(str(err)) from None
    487         return value
    488

BoxKeyError: "'Box' object has no attribute 'd'"
```

items.title: [5.0.0] Spurious values appear in default Box "repr"
items.body:
```python
>>> b = box.Box(default_box=True)
>>> b
<Box: {}>
>>> b.first = ''
>>> b
<Box: {'_obj_': {}, '_oleobj_': {'GetTypeInfoCount': {}}, 'first': ''}>
>>> dict(b)
{'_obj_': <Box: {}>, '_oleobj_': <Box: {'GetTypeInfoCount': {}}>, 'first': ''}
```

items.title: Recast BoxList types
flatten dot keys
items.body:
I have implemented support for dot keys by sub-classing Box and using it for two years by now.
Among other things it provides an alternative data model which essentially flattens the hierarchy - a useful approach in certain cases.
To fully support this model I needed to allow also flat iteration over the data elements.
It was implemented by adding optional parameter in `keys` and `items` and `values` members.

For example, for keys:
```python
def keys(self, depth=False):
    ...
```
So that
```python
box.keys(depth=True)
# ['a.b.c', 'a.b.d', 'a.x.y']
```
That makes the 'flat' model complete and can be implemented with minimal code and performance overhead.

Do you think it could be generic enough to include into the package?

items.title: frozen_box propagation into sub-nodes
items.body:
Is that a designed behaviour:

```python
hash(Box({'x': {'y': 2}}, frozen_box=True))
# OK!

hash(Box({'x': Box({'y': 2})}, frozen_box=True))
# TypeError: unhashable type: 'Box'
```
When combining a structure from pieces a mixed dict/Box hierarchy may emerge,
and to make it frozen one should now traverse it and change box-node by node, or 
some ugly thing like that:

```python:
frozen_box = Box(Box(struct).to_dict(), frozen_box=True)
```
An alternative would be to make sure that `Box(struct, frozen_box=True)`
would make sure all the sub-boxes are frozen too.

What do you think?
Thanks

items.title: Typo in README: 55 should be int
items.body:
In README.rst, in the section [Box Recast Values](https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/README.rst#box-recast-values), in the example code it has

    print(type(my_box.new_key.id))
    # 55

As the `type` is being printed, it looks like that should be 

    print(type(my_box.new_key.id))
    # int

items.body:
I'd like to inherit from Box so that I can add some attributes during creation, particularly with __init__ - are there any examples of doing this out there, or is this verboten?

When I do the following, I get the following errors:
```
class MLBox(Box):
    def __init__(self, semantic_version, schema_type: MLSchemaTypes, **kwargs):
        self.__version = SemVer.parse(semantic_version)
        self.__schema_type = schema_type

        super().__init__(**kwargs)
```

Error:
```
TypeError: __init__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'schema_type'
```

items.title: Jupyter's autoreload fails when subclassing Box
items.body:
This is a little obscure and probably not that common of a use case, but I'd like to subclass `Box` to modify the `__str__` method.

I'm also using this in a Jupyter notebook, and for the sake of convenience I'd like to use the `autoreload` extension so I don't have to keep re-running my import statements after every change to external files.

Steps to reproduce:

- Create a python module where you subclass `Box`
```python
# sub.py
from box import Box
class Sub(Box):
    pass
```
- In a Jupyter notebook, load the `autoreload` extension with mode `2`
```
%load_ext autoreload
%autoreload 2
```
- In the notebook, import the new class and instantiate an object from it
```python
from sub import Sub
d = Sub()
```
- Re-save the python file containing the subclass definition (this notifies `autoreload` that something in the module has changed), then re-run the aforementioned notebook cell

This results in 
```
[autoreload of sub failed: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/autoreload.py", line 245, in check
    superreload(m, reload, self.old_objects)
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/autoreload.py", line 410, in superreload
    update_generic(old_obj, new_obj)
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/autoreload.py", line 347, in update_generic
    update(a, b)
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/autoreload.py", line 317, in update_class
    update_instances(old, new)
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/IPython/extensions/autoreload.py", line 280, in update_instances
    ref.__class__ = new
  File "/opt/anaconda/miniconda3/envs/ai/lib/python3.7/site-packages/box/box.py", line 369, in __setattr__
    raise BoxKeyError(f'Key name "{key}" is protected')
box.exceptions.BoxKeyError: 'Key name "__class__" is protected'
]
```

I've tried and failed to find the cause of the error (apart from the fact that `__class__` is part of `Box._protected_keys`)

items.title: Feature: Compare 2 or more box
items.body: I tried and failed to look to have a compare functionality that can provide a report of what's different between 2 boxes. I notice I can compare 2 Boxes with a comparison operator e.g. `Box(a=1, b=dict(c=1)) == Box(a=1, b=dict(c=1))` however it would be nice to have a special `Box.compare(box2,...)` method that also generates a report (maybe a Box object itself)

```python
>>> b1 = Box({'a': {'from': {'b':1}}})
>>> b1.a.xfrom
<Box: {'b': 1}>
>>> b3 = Box({'a': {'from': {'b':1}}}, default_box=True)
```

items.title: to_json() creates str
items.body:
Given a JSON example (Python 3.7.4 for all):
```
json_string = """
{  "entity": "ENTITY" }
"""
entity = Box.from_json(json_string)
print(entity)
print(type(entity))
```

I get,
```
{'entity': 'ENTITY'}
<class 'box.box.Box'>
```

Doing the same thing with YAML, given,
```
yaml_string = """
entity: "ENTITY"
"""

entity_temp = Box.from_yaml(yaml_string)
entity = entity_temp.to_json()
print(entity)
print(type(entity))
```

I get,
```
{"entity": "ENTITY"}
<class 'str'>
```

In the first example I can use the `entity` variable directly with `requests.put(...,json=entity,...)`. The second one I have to json.loads()... which is pretty much why I was starting to use Box in the first place.

Your documentation is clear that to_json outputs as a string (or a filename).

Similar to json.load and json.loads, at some point maybe to_json() and to_jsons() might be useful?

Thanks for the useful work on this library. It's handy.

items.title: Remove `box_it_up` reference from readme
Also, all new dict and lists added to a Box or BoxList object are converted automatically.
items.body:
Is there a reason that there is not an option to turn this behavior off?

There are times when I just want the Dict that I give Box to be dot accessible. By ALWAYS converting ANYTHING that looks like it could be a list or dict into a bloated Box without my permission, I just turned a 0.0000001 sec operation into a .... well it hasnt finished yet kind of operation in my Jupyter NB.

It turns out that one of the keys in that original dict contained the human genome's gene-set as a key-value pair.

items.title: Issue with Conversions and CamelCase in 4.0
items.body: Camelcase and some other transforms were not properly ported for the 4.0 release, fixing in 4.1

items.title: default_box_attr does not accept values which evaluate to False
items.body:
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/561548983c8956eac486c8cf99f5801e1155972a/box/box.py#L177
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/561548983c8956eac486c8cf99f5801e1155972a/box/box.py#L200

Giving a default value such as None, False, 0, "" or an empty collection does not work, since they evaluate to False at the `or` operators in the referenced lines and Box reverts to `cls.__class__`.

Currently, this can be circumvented in the following way:
```python
from box import Box


class OtumeelFactory:
    def __init__(self, val):
        self.val = val

    def spawn(self):
        b = self.val

        class Otumeel:
            def __new__(self):
                return b

        return Otumeel


black_marsh = OtumeelFactory(0)
thief = black_marsh.spawn()

box = Box(default_box=True, default_box_attr=thief)
# It just works
print(box.t)


black_marsh = OtumeelFactory(None)
thief = black_marsh.spawn()

box = Box(default_box=True, default_box_attr=thief)
# 16 times the default values
print(box.t)


black_marsh = OtumeelFactory(False)
thief = black_marsh.spawn()

box = Box(default_box=True, default_box_attr=thief)
# See that False? You can return it
print(box.t)
```

items.title: Document incorrect about 'default_box_attr' behaviour
items.body:
In document 
> default_box_attr will first check if it is callable, and will call the object if it is, otherwise it will see if has the copy attribute and will call that, lastly, will just use the provided item as is

But due to Box [__init__](https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/box/box.py#L200)
```
        self._box_config.update({
            'default_box': default_box,
            'default_box_attr': default_box_attr or self.__class__,
```
When  default_box_attr is logical false ('', [], {} etc) it's actually replaced by Box.

This code won't work as expected:
```
x = Box(default_box=True, default_box_attr='')
x.abc  # returns a Box
```
It has to be
```
x = Box(default_box=True, default_box_attr=str)
x.abc  # returns ''
```
So `list` for `[]`, `int` for `0` etc

At least version 3.4.6 is working with `default_box_attr=''`.

Suggestion:
Either change document to indicate this detail, or change code to accept `'', [], 0` etc.
Possible fix is
```
            'default_box_attr': self.__class__ if default_box_attr is None else default_box_attr,
```

items.title: Box.update is slow
items.body:
Is Box.update supposed to be much slower than dict.update? I expected the performance to be comparable, and ran into trouble. The code below shows the timing for dict.update and Box.
.update

```python
import random
import box
import string
import time

def random_string(N):
    return ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits, k=N))


a = dict((random_string(64), 0) for i in range(10**3))
for i in a:
    a[i.upper()] = 0

b = box.Box(dict((random_string(64), 0) for i in range(10)))
c = dict((random_string(64), 0) for i in range(10))

st = time.time()
c.update(a)
et = time.time()
print(et - st)

st = time.time()
b.update(a)
et = time.time()
print(et - st)
```
Output:
```
2.09808349609375e-05
4.840667724609375
```
With
```
Python 3.7.5 (default, Nov  1 2019, 02:16:32) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.8)] on darwin
```

```
>>> import box

>>> print(my_box.b.c[1].e)
my_value
>>> print(my_box['b.c[1].e']) 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Python36\lib\site-packages\box\box.py", line 330, in __getitem__
    return self[first_item][children]
  File "C:\Python36\lib\site-packages\box\box.py", line 334, in __getitem__
    raise BoxKeyError(str(err)) from None
box.exceptions.BoxKeyError: "'c[1].e'"
```

Can I get the value by using dot notaion when key in a list?

Thanks!

items.title: Regression due to ruamel.yaml
items.body:
Potentially dangerous regression in config box, due to the new `ruamel.yaml` dependency.

```
>>> from box import ConfigBox
>>> b = ConfigBox.from_yaml("kill_all_humans_mode: no")
>>> if b.kill_all_humans_mode: 
...     print("ok, killing all humans...") 
...
ok, killing all humans...
```

Same problem with `box.Box`. Our test suite caught this, but others might not be so lucky.  [ruamel isn't exactly a drop-in replacement for yaml](https://yaml.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pyyaml.html#differences-with-pyyaml), despite claims to the contrary (ruamel defaults to spec 1.2 and yaml is spec 1.1).

I would advise to make the `toml` and `ruamel.yaml` dependencies optional (or "soft" dependencies, like it was in 3.x) since users might prefer other providers such as `pytoml` and `PyYAML` and you don't want to tie their hands here. 

Personally, I can not use `box>=4` at all because the `ruamel.yaml` has an [insane installer](https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/src/default/setup.py) which, for various reasons, does not work in the prod environment at $EMPLOYER.

items.title: Problem with references to subdicts in Box 4.0.x
items.body:
Given this program:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import box

info = box.Box({'initial': {1: 'uno', 2: 'dos'}}, default_box=True)
d = info.other = {}
d[3] = 'three'
d[4] = 'four'

print('Box version: ', box.__version__)
print(info.to_yaml())
```

With Box 4.0.4 I get this result:

```
Box version:  4.0.4
initial:
  1: uno
  2: dos
other: {}
```

Prior to Box 4.0.1 I got the correct result:

```
Box version:  3.4.6
initial:
  1: uno
  2: dos
other:
  3: three
  4: four
```

items.title: Remove pytest-runner
items.body:
Line https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/6d8790e35b6d2f20eb3bb0f4b450b0413daa94c1/setup.py#L36 should be removed.

Issue 1 (my immediate one): I'm using automated builds for an embedded device and the build environment is minimal, and doesn't include pytest. Since I'm not testing.
Issue 2: https://pypi.org/project/pytest-runner/#deprecation-notice

items.title: Change box back to non-lazy creation
items.body: While it did save time on the initial ingest of data, there have been may side cases where lazy loading caused issues down the road in hard to predict ways. For 4.0 I am planning to change back to convert on store.

items.title: Small typo in box.py
items.body: Should read specific rather than specfic.

items.title: Update() is broken as of 3.4.3
items.body:
Given this sample code:
```
import box

if __name__ == '__main__':
    b = box.Box({
        'one': {
            'sub1': 'monkey',
            'sub2': 'goat',
        }
    }, box_it_up = True)

    print(f'box: {b}')
    print(f'one is a {type(b.one)}')
    print(f'expect monkey: {b.one.sub1}')
    print(f'expect goat: {b.one.sub2}')
            
    b.update({'one': {'sub2': 'alpaca'}})
    print(f'one is a {type(b.one)}')
    print(f'expect monkey: {b.one.sub1}')
    print(f'expect alpaca: {b.one.sub2}')
```

It works with < 3.4.3:
```
box: {'one': {'sub1': 'monkey', 'sub2': 'goat'}}
one is a <class 'box.Box'>
expect monkey: monkey
expect goat: goat
one is a <class 'box.Box'>
expect monkey: monkey
expect alpaca: alpaca
```

 But using >= 3.4.3, this is the result:
```
box: {'one': {'sub1': 'monkey', 'sub2': 'goat'}}
one is a <class 'box.Box'>
expect monkey: monkey
expect goat: goat
one is a <class 'dict'>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test.py", line 16, in <module>
    print(f'expect monkey: {b.one.sub1}')
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'sub1'
```
I notice there were changes to the `update()` method.

(edited: added some code to print out the types, which show the difference)

items.title: to_yaml() does not honor ordered_box
items.body:
```python
In [1]: from box import Box
In [2]: ordered_box = Box(ordered_box=True)
In [3]: ordered_box.zlast = 'first'
In [4]: ordered_box.afirst = 'last'
In [5]: ordered_box.keys()
Out[5]: ['zlast', 'afirst']  # correct, as expected
In [6]: ordered_box.to_yaml()
Out[6]: 'afirst: last\nzlast: first\n'  # not ordered as expected!
```

YAML really looks better when ordered logically, not arbitrarily!

items.title: Bug when popping keys that contain twice-nested dicts before viewing an object's `repr()`
items.body:
Hi, I recently came across `Box` and am excited to adopt it for Prefect (see https://github.com/PrefectHQ/prefect/pull/1518). However, one of our unit tests highlighted what appears to be an odd bug.

The following code results in a `BoxKeyError`:
```
from box import Box

x = Box({"a": {"b": {"c": 1}}})

# error
x.pop('a')

# calling repr works (or just examining the object)
x = Box({"a": {"b": {"c": 1}}})
repr(x)
x.pop('a')

# happens for any twice-nested key
Box({"a": {"b": {"c": {'d':1}}}}).a.pop('b') #error
```

Basically, if you try to `pop` a key that has two nested keys under it, you get an error.

What makes this really weird and Heisenbug-ish is that if you inspect the `Box` object interactively or even call `repr()` on it, everything works fine. I don't know Box well enough to trace the error yet but it seems to be some deferred initialization of the recursive Box objects -- maybe in the `_box_heritage` tracker?

I hope this example helps track down the problem.

items.title: On Python 3.7.0 when a Box object is passed to the dict constructor it is converted back to dict recursively
items.body:
When a `Box` object is passed to the `dict` consturctor the `Box` object is recursively converted to `dict` on `Python 3.7.0`, but on other versions (I tried it with `3.6.9`, and from `3.7.1`) only the first level converted to `dict`.

Examples:

```
Python 3.7.0 (default, Oct 16 2018, 07:10:55)
[GCC 6.3.0 20170516] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from box import Box
>>> d = {"a": {"b": "B"}}
>>> b = Box(d)
>>> dict(b)
{'a': {'b': 'B'}}

Python 3.7.1 (default, Nov 16 2018, 22:26:09)
[GCC 6.3.0 20170516] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from box import Box
>>> d = {"a": {"b": "B"}}
>>> b = Box(d)
>>> dict(b)
{'a': <Box: {'b': 'B'}>}
```

items.title: Write-only default box
items.body:
Hi!

First of all, thank you very much for this neat library, it really comes in handy in a project I'm currently working on, but I've stumbled upon one case that is currently not handled by Box.

It's something that I called `write_default_box`. Its behavior would be similar to the default box, but only when trying to set an attribute. When trying to simply get an attribute that does not exists, it would still return `BoxKeyError`.

I'm willing to work on this and propose a pull request, but first I wanted to consult you and ask whether you see a possibility to implement something like this and so on.

Thanks for your time!

--- 

An example of how this new behavior would work is below:

```python

> box = Box(writeonly_default_box=True)
> box

Box({})

> box.nested.field

BoxKeyError: "'Box' object has no attribute 'test'"

> box.nested.field = "value"
> box

Box({
	"nested": {
		"field": "value"
	}
})
```

items.title: __deepcopy__ magic method of Box doesn't copy _box_config

Hello,

The following example show how `__deepcopy__` doesn't copy camel_killer_box from _box_config to the new object:

```python
from box import Box
from copy import deepcopy

dictionary = {'aB': 1}
config = Box(dictionary, camel_killer_box=True)
deepcopy_config = deepcopy(config)

config.a_b  # 1
deepcopy_config.a_b  # error

config._box_config['camel_killer_box']  # True
deepcopy_config._box_config['camel_killer_box']  # False
```

This is the error of `deepcopy_config.a_b`:

items.title: Box options not propagated when using setdefault / append
items.body:
I have the code below.. should it work?

I can see why it is failing. The initial Box is set with default_box=True. Later, I add an array and append an empty object object. When I do this, I am not able to use the default_box functionality, and just keep on dot'ing down the Box

Easier to explain in code:

```
    a = Box(default_box=True)
    a.b.c.setdefault('d',[])
    a.b.c.d.append({})
    a.b.c.d[0].e.f = 1

...
>        if self._box_config['default_box']:
>              return self.__get_default(item)
>           raise BoxKeyError(str(err))
E           BoxKeyError: "'Box' object has no attribute 'e'"
> AttributeError: 'BoxList' object has no attribute 'e'
```

I can see why - the new box which was appended, appears not to be set with default_box=True

I tried this, thinking it would fix it, but it does not:

```
    a = Box(default_box=True)
    a.b.c.setdefault('d',[])
    a.b.c.d.append(Box(default_box=True))
    a.b.c.d[0].e.f = 1

> AttributeError: 'BoxList' object has no attribute 'e'
```

Is what I am attempting possible? I need to create big Elasticsearch json queries, which have nested arrays of objects. It is ugly to deal with in normal python, but Box really looks like it can help - apart from this issue. 

It looks like the original box_options are not propagated when using append. I can see in box.py that the parent options are not passed to BoxList (line 672 and 815) - I attempted a hotfix to pass them in, but didn't seem to work..

items.title: .get does not return default for default dict
items.body:
Currently for default_box a new empty box object will be returned by `.get`, whereas it should be reutnring the 'default' passed to get if it does not exist.

It should only return a box object (or other specified default dict replacement) if the `default` param is set to `None`

items.title: Backwards compatibility pledge
items.body:
My goal with 4.0 is that with every behavioral change (even fixes) will be backwards compatible. So that if someone's code is reliant upon a 'broken' version, updating will not instantly break their code. 

Instead custom cases will be made for that version with a depreciation warning for at least 1 month before it is removed / cleaned up.

items.title: Remove Python 2.x support
items.body:
Python 2.x support will be dropped on 10/10/2019 with the release of Box 4.0. 

I will not provide any updates to the Box 3.x or previous version after 1\1\2020.

items.title: Underscore('_') removal too arbitrary in _safe_attr
items.body:
Consider this code:
```python
from box import Box
b = Box(_out = 'preserved')
b.update({'out': 'updated'})
# expected:
# {'_out': 'preserved', 'out': 'updated'}
# observed:
# {'_out': 'updated'}
# out lost
```
I thought this was designed intentionally at the beginning. However, when I digged into the code, I found the problem was due to https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/box.py#L151
```python
    out = ''
    for character in attr:
        out += character if character in allowed else "_"
    out = out.strip("_")  <- L151
```
This arbitrarily removed all underscores in the key, even the originally assigned ones.  
I won't say this is a bug, but really confusing.  

Maybe we could use some unique characters to replace the characters that are not allowed, which will be removed later.

Say:  
```python
    out = ''
    for character in attr:
        out += character if character in allowed else "@"
    out = out.strip("@")
```

items.title: Any plan convert to toml?
items.body: ### Any plan convert box to toml? Just as method to_yaml.

items.title: Consider using solid class name instead of self.__class__
items.body:
Hi @cdgriffith,

Really appreciated that you acted so quick to add `box_intact_types`.
Now I have another issue when I was trying to extend `Box` class with some more features, personally:
```python
from box import Box

class Box2(Box):
    # My other methods go here ...

b = Box2(a=1)
b # <Box: {'a': 1}>
```
Everything worked fine, however, when I tried to copy the box:
```python
c = b.copy()
```
I have got an exception:
```shell
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RecursionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-f0d8dd24f807> in <module>
      5 
      6 b = Box2(a=1)
----> 7 b.copy()

/.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/box.py in copy(self)
    402 
    403     def copy(self):
--> 404         return self.__class__(super(self.__class__, self).copy())
    405 
    406     def __copy__(self):

... last 1 frames repeated, from the frame below ...

/.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/box.py in copy(self)
    402 
    403     def copy(self):
--> 404         return self.__class__(super(self.__class__, self).copy())
    405 
    406     def __copy__(self):

RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
```

Then I modified the source code of `copy`:
```python
    def copy(self):
        return Box(super(Box, self).copy())
```
every thing worked fine.

Maybe consider using a solid class name instead of `self.__class__`?  
Or I have to copy the `copy` method to each subclass of `Box`.

items.title: Keep object extended from dict/list intact
items.body:
Hi @cdgriffith,

I am the one who proposed `ordered_box`.  
I was recently bothered by `Box` turning some objects that are inherited from `dict/list` into `Box/BoxList`.  
Consider the following codes:

```python
from box import Box

class MyList(list): 
    def sq(self):
        return [x*x for x in self]
	
b = Box(a = MyList([1,2,4]))
b.a.sq()
# AttributeError: 'BoxList' object has no attribute 'sq'
# Expect [1,4,16]
```

I extended `list` to add some extra methods for convenience. However, when it was changed by `Box` into a `BoxList`, then I lost my method `sq`.
Is it possible to keep the objects of extended `dict/list` intact, but convert the raw `dict/list`s?   

One simple way is to check the `__bases__`, if it is `(object, )` then it should be a raw `dict/list`:
```python
def _israwinstance(obj, klass):
    return isinstance(obj, klass) and obj.__class__.__bases__ \
       and obj.__class__.__bases__[0] is object
```

Thanks,
Panwen

items.title: Ability to recast the type of parameter(s)
Can I use variables to access a key?
items.body:
I have a gigantic JSON object being returned via an API call. I am really only interested in a few fields in this response object. I'm trying to set up a config file of some kind that I can use to only get the fields I need. 

```
    fields:
        - field1
        - field2
        - field3.subfield1
```

This is the config I'm thinking, but it's not set in stone. 

This works for the top level elements:

```
devices = {
        'field1': 'Value of F1',
        'field2': 'Value of F2',
        'field3': [
                {
                    'subfield1': 'Value of subfield1',
                    'subfield2': 'Value of subfield2'
                }
            ],
        'field4': 'Not wanted'
    }

wanted_fields = ['field1', 'field2', 'field3.subfield1']

box_device = Box(devices)
for field in wanted_fields:
    print("{field} => {value}".format(field=field, value=box_device[field]))
```

Output:

```
field1 => Value of F1
field2 => Value of F2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/myuser/.virtualenvs/jsontests/lib/python3.6/site-packages/box.py", line 412, in __getitem__
    value = super(Box, self).__getitem__(item)
KeyError: 'field3.subfield1'
```

This makes sense, because the dictionary path to that key is actually `box_device['field3']['subfield1']` 

However, if I attempt to change the print statement to use `field` as a variable, I get this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "box_test.py", line 33, in <module>
    print("{field} => {value}".format(field=field, value=box_device.field))
  File "/home/myuser/.virtualenvs/jsontests/lib/python3.6/site-packages/box.py", line 511, in __getattr__
    raise BoxKeyError(str(err))
box.BoxKeyError: "'Box' object has no attribute 'field'"
```

---

Question:

How can I access keys and sub-keys in a variable manner? I'd like something like `mybox.field` where `field` is a string containing keys I care about and that can be multileveled (ie. `field` could be `field1` or `field2.subfield1`)  I really would like to use dot notation to do this so that I can have clean and easy to understand configuration files.

When I run this:

```python
import box
import sys

print(sys.version)
print(box.__version__)

data = {
    "fine": ['this', 'that', 'the other'],

}

print("# working ########################################")
a = box.Box(data)
print(a.fine)
print(a.fine[1])

print("# broken ########################################")
print(a.items)
print(a.items[1])

print("# also broken but we don't get this far ########################################")
print(a.keys)
print(a.keys[1])
```

I get this:

```
3.7.1 (default, Nov 28 2018, 11:51:54)
[Clang 10.0.0 (clang-1000.11.45.5)]
3.2.3
# working ########################################
['this', 'that', 'the other']
that
# broken ########################################
<bound method Box.items of <Box: {'fine': ['this', 'that', 'the other'], 'items': ['this', 'that', 'the other'], 'keys': ['this', 'that', 'the other']}>>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "parse_json_with_box.py", line 20, in <module>

TypeError: 'method' object is not subscriptable
```

This seems related to #62 but is still a problem is version 3.2.3.

items.title: Deafault value in case of key not found
items.body:
Thank you for your software! 

Is there a way to receive a `None`, or a default value, rather than a `BoxKeyError` like we could in: `get(key, default)` if the key is not found in the `Box`?

items.title: bug leading to recursive list
items.body:
The following code should print `[['foo']]` but instead prints `[[...]]` showing that a auto-referential list has been created.
```python
from box import Box

def bl():
    b = Box()
    bl = b.setdefault("l", [])
    bl.append(["foo"])
    print(bl)
```

Issue lies on https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/box.py#L771 (or in the append function at https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/box.py#L802) that detects self referential entities.
The `id(iterable)` is not robust enought as two object may have the same id if the first object has been garbage collected.
One can see this in the example below
```python
def bl():
    b = Box()
    l1 = []
    bl = b.setdefault("l", l1)
    del l1    # comment this to see that now it works as l1 is not garbage collected
    bl.append(["foo"])
    print(bl)
```
A fix could be to replace https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/master/box.py#L771 by
```python
        self.box_org_ref = id(iterable) if iterable else 0
```

    del self[key]
  File "/mnt/d/projekte/python/envs/depmgmt/bin/box.py", line 560, in __delitem__

Is this working as intended ? I would expect to get the given default value when the key is not existant ?

Thank you...

items.title: AttributeError if update from a dict with protected key name
items.body:
```python
In [1]: a=box.Box()
In [2]: a.update({'items': 0})
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-ccd724442f09> in <module>()
----> 1 a.update({'items': 0})

~/.pyenv/versions/3.6.6/bin/box.py in update(self, item, **kwargs)
    669                 v = BoxList(v)
    670             try:
--> 671                 self.__setattr__(k, v)
    672             except TypeError:
    673                 self.__setitem__(k, v)

~/.pyenv/versions/3.6.6/bin/box.py in __setattr__(self, key, value)
    540             raise BoxError('Box is frozen')
    541         if key in self._protected_keys:
--> 542             raise AttributeError("Key name '{0}' is protected".format(key))
    543         if key == '_box_config':
    544             return object.__setattr__(self, key, value)

AttributeError: Key name 'items' is protected
```

this breaks the original method of dict, and box can have such protected keys, just without dot accessing

because i use defaultbox only so i temporarily hotfix this line:

https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/ae49ac284e993aae9f195b1e6a10029f63e7238e/box.py#L671

to:

```python
self[k] = v
```

items.title: py3.7 collections deprecation warning
items.body:
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/ae49ac284e993aae9f195b1e6a10029f63e7238e/box.py#L450

```
DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is deprecated, and in 3.8 it will stop working
    elif isinstance(default_value, collections.Callable):
```

items.title: Box __hash__ does not adhere to the specification
items.body:
Per [Python docs](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#object.__hash__), `__hash__` should have this property:

> The only required property is that objects which compare equal have the same hash value;

However:

```
def f():
  return Box(data={'Python': 'Rocks', 'inferior': ['java', 'cobol']}, frozen_box=True)

b1 = f()
b2 = f()
print(b1 == b2)
print(hash(b1), hash(b2))
print(set([b1, b2]))
```

yields:

```
True
-7253217714821940563 1337995706200090896
{<Box: {'data': {'Python': 'Rocks', 'inferior': ('java', 'cobol')}}>, <Box: {'data': {'Python': 'Rocks', 'inferior': ('java', 'cobol')}}>}
```

This also makes is unusable for using in `set`s, as seen in the above message.

The reason for this looks to be due to [\_\_hash__](https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/ae49ac284e993aae9f195b1e6a10029f63e7238e/box.py#L349) having a random `uuid4` included in the calculation:

```
                hashing = hash(uuid4().hex)
```

Is there a reason for this line?

items.title: Treat None values as unexisting keys for default_box
items.body:
Hi, 

thanks a lot for your project, it's currently helping me a lot :)
one feature i missed is the ability to treat None values as if there was no key defined.

like in this example.

```python
b=Box({'brol': None}, default_box=True)
b.brol.truc
```
gives 
>Traceback (most recent call last):
>  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
>AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'truc'

but this works as exepected
```python 
b=Box({}, default_box=True)
b.brol.truc
```


many many thanks 👍

items.title: hierarchical path as string
items.body:
Would you consider to support dotted string as a access key to sub boxes:
```python
b=Box(dotted=True)

b.c.d.e = 10
b['c.d.e'] == b.c.d.e
```
That is, to have an equivalence between those two notations.
If positive, then also to support some corresponding functions for traversing (for example):
```python
b = Box(dotted=True)
b.c = dict(e=1, f=2)
b.a = dict(b=3, c=4)
[*Box.keys(dotted=True)]
# ['c.d.e', 'c.d.f', 'a.b', 'a.c']
```
Thanks!

items.title: Tests fail on python 3.7 due to change in pickling
BoxList(args, frozen_box=True) doesn't make the outer list immutable.
items.body:
`BoxList(args, frozen_box=True)` should return a `BoxList` which will raise `BoxError: BoxList is frozen` on item modification such as:
```
box_list[0] = "new_value"
box_list += [1,2]
box_list.append("new")
box_list.extend([1,2,3])
box_list.insert(..)
box_list.pop(..)
box_list.remove(..)
box_list.reverse(..)
box_list.sort(..)
```
I know that this can be sorted out using `tuple(BoxList(args, frozen_box=True))` but would like `BoxList` behavior to be consistent with `Box` behavior when `frozen_box` is True

items.title: Versions of ruamel.yaml since 0.15 generate warning about Loader for Box.from_yaml()
items.body:
Box 3.2.0, Python 3.6.2, Windows 7

For versions of ruamel.yaml since 0.15, the following files:

== 1.yaml ==
```yaml
greeting: Hello!
date: 2018-01-01
```

== 1.py ==
```python
import box

info = box.Box.from_yaml(filename='1.yaml')
print(info)
```

Generates the following output (paths edited):

```
<path>\box.py:112: UnsafeLoaderWarning
The default 'Loader' for 'load(stream)' without further arguments can be unsafe.
Use 'load(stream, Loader=ruamel.yaml.Loader)' explicitly if that is OK.
Alternatively include the following in your code:

  import warnings
  warnings.simplefilter('ignore', ruamel.yaml.error.UnsafeLoaderWarning)

In most other cases you should consider using 'safe_load(stream)'
  data = yaml.load(f, **kwargs)
{'greeting': 'Hello!', 'date': datetime.date(2018, 1, 1)}
```

items.title: Feature Request: LayeredBox
items.body:
When using `Box` to represent a configuration hierarchy, it would be great to be able to have a `LayeredBox` virtually merging multiple `Box`es in layers. That way, `Box`es containing content from say a system wide, user specific and directory specific configuration could be combined while retaining the ability to write back changes using a round-trip yaml parser to preserve formatting and comments in the config provided by the user.

The `LayeredBox` would probably require some flags defining the way merging is done recursively. Should dictionaries at all levels be combined, or should they be overwritten? Should lists be overwritten or merged by appending? Typically, you'd want dictionaries to be merged and lists to be overwritten I think. It's a semantic decision though.

items.title: Support for non-string keys
items.body:
I specifically ran into this issue when calling to_dict on a Box instance with an integer key. A TypeError is raised on this line:
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/37ad92655da7dc31d3cd55ffab304ea2a0d68a72/box.py#L524
`TypeError: attribute name must be string, not 'int'`
I saw the issue when using Python 3.5.2.

The following works for an integer key:
`self[key] = value`
so the change may be as simple as adding TypeError to line 525:
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/37ad92655da7dc31d3cd55ffab304ea2a0d68a72/box.py#L525

This was not an issue in 2.0 and most likely later versions, although it may not have been intentionally supported:
https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/blob/8340399c659b274d9bdec452684f4ace0d844164/box.py#L71
As a result I would argue this is a bug not a feature request.

items.title: camel_case_killer conflicts with conversion_box and default_box
items.body:
Hey!
I've recently started using your awesome package and it has been a delight. Unfortunately, I encountered couple of issues with the `camel_killer_box` option:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1483099/35511821-1a6a47d0-0506-11e8-932a-af350abd1de4.png)

I've tested it on Python 2 and 3. 
Copy-pasteable reproduction code:
```python
from box import Box

b = Box({
    'SomeKey': 999
}, camel_killer_box=True, conversion_box=True)

assert b.some_key == 999 # Cool, works as expected
assert b.SomeKey == 999  # Should not work because of conversion_box=True!

# When using default_box=True, things get even worse:
b = Box({
    'SomeKey': 999
}, camel_killer_box=True, conversion_box=True, default_box=True)

assert b.SomeKey == 999   # Same issue
assert b.some_key == Box({})  # Oh man, the default_box is prioritized over camel_killer_box...
```

I'm working on a fix for this, but I'll be happy for input.

items.title: Can we keep the order of the keys?
items.body:
Just like `OrderedDict`, maybe we can have something like `OrderedBox`.
Then we should be able to have something like this:
```python
from box import OrderedBox
ob = OrderedBox()
ob.c = 1
ob.b = 2
ob.a = 3

assert ob.keys() != ['a', 'b', 'c']
assert ob.keys() == ['c', 'b', 'a']
```

items.title: BUG: key in box always return True when default_box=True
items.body:
For default box, any key membership test returns `True` even when they are not in box while `has_key` correctly returns False.

```
>>> box = Box(default_box=True)
>>> print('a' in box)
True
>>> print(box.has_key('a'))
False
```

items.title: .get can not return Box item
items.body: Can't believe I missed this. Need to override .get

items.title: `items()` / `keys()` can return unboxed objects
items.body:
Test case:

```python
>>> import box
>>> box.__version__
'3.1.0'
>>> b = box.Box()
>>> b.foo = {}
>>> b.values()
dict_values([{}])
>>> b.foo # Force conversion by accessing the key
<Box: {}>
>>> b.values()
dict_values([<Box: {}>])

```

it is very complete and very thoroughly tested. you may find it inspiring. ;)

items.title: Box raises an AttributeError on nonexistent key, should raise a KeyError (or custom error)
items.body:
When accessing a key which does not exist, an AttributeError will be raised. This sends the wrong message (in my opinion), implying that the user is attempting to access an attribute on the `Box` object which does not exist. When the true behavior is just syntactic sugar over a dict object, a KeyError seems more appropriate. I get that this is a philosophical opinion, so I could certainly be convinced that AttributeError is appropriate. 

Repro in python repl:

```python
Python 2.7.10 (default, Aug 22 2015, 20:33:39)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 7.0.0 (clang-700.0.59.1)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from box import Box
>>>
>>> b = Box({})
>>> b.attr
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/jiso/projects/jwplayer-python/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/box.py", line 385, in __getattr__
    raise err
AttributeError: 'Box' object has no attribute 'attr'
```

Actual: in above example, AttributeError is raised
Expected: KeyError is raised

items.title: Cannot pickle
items.body:
```
pickle.dump(Box({}), open('/tmp/test.p', 'wb'))
test = pickle.load(open('/tmp/test.p', 'rb'))
```

caused endless `KeyError: '_box_config'` and then `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object`

python version: 3.6

items.title: Collection ABCs not used on Python 2.7
items.body:
On Python 2.7 there is no collections.abc module, instead the collection base types are available directly in the collections module
The current code says:
```
try:
    from collections.abc import Mapping, Iterable
except ImportError:
    Mapping = dict
    Iterable = (tuple, list)
```

I recommend putting from collections import Iterable, Mapping as the except case, possibly still including the fallback for even earlier Pythons but possibly not as this totally changes how the library works rather unexpectedly. At the very least, a warning should happen when this fallback mode is used.

items.body: odd anomaly seen once, needs more testing passing through queues.

items.title: Box.copy() returns a dictionary
items.body:
Is this intentional?

```
d = dict.fromkeys([1,2,3,4],0)
d = box.Box(d)
print(type(d))
print(type(d.copy()))
---------------------------
>> <class 'box.Box'>
>> <class 'dict'>
```

items.title: Figure out best way to deal with circular references
items.body:
As discovered with https://github.com/cdgriffith/Box/issues/20

Issue can be duplicated with:

```python
troll_dict = {}
troll_dict ['e'] = {'g': troll_dict}

bx = Box(troll_dict)
bx.e.g
<Box: {'e': {'g': {'e': {'g': {'e': {'g': {'e': {'g': {'e': {'g': {'e': ..................
```

Also would include way to detect and raise custom `BoxError` instead of related recursive built in error for functions like `box_it_up`. 

Other libraries such as `addict` and `DotMap` cannot handle even first level circular references, so may not be an easy or worthwhile thing to address.  

Only current thought on how to address it would be to keep list of references to original objects that were converted, and upon creation of sub-boxes check all other previously generated ones to see if any have that link already and re-reference the newly created sub-box. The issue is that this would be very memory and process heavy for a rare issue check.

items.title: Allow customizable safety character for conversion box.
items.body: Currently using `x` as a prepend to conflicting keys to convert to attributes. May be confusing as pointed out by https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=askvictor .

items.title: PyPI RST is not working even though it passed checkdocs
Aliased keys can be overwritten without warning
items.body:
Box doesn't warn when data is shadowed 

```
>>> d = {'to': 'chris@cdgriffith.com', 'from': 'hey@wimglenn.com', 'subject': 'bugs'}
>>> b = Box(d)
>>> b.to
'chris@cdgriffith.com'
>>> b.from
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
>>> b.xfrom
'hey@wimglenn.com'
>>> Box({'to': 'chris', 'from': 'wim', 'subject': 'bugs', 'xfrom': 'wat'}).xfrom
'wat'

```

items.title: box blows recursion stack
Performance metrics
items.body: Oversimplifying the whole library would imply `JSON -> PyDict with dot notation` is what is being done here. As parsing JSON can be very slow, I am very much interested in some perf numbers as to how it scales. Can you please add these metrics in README ?

items.title: No Output in Default Sublime Build Window
items.body:
OS:
 Windows 7 
 Sublime 2.0 

Works in terminal.   
Low priority. 
See gif.  When running under default python build env runs without error but not of the links show up.

```python
from box import Box

class Job(object):
	"""Configure the job object via runner."""
	def __init__(self, **kwargs):
		self.job = Box(kwargs)


job = {
	'uuid': None,
	'started' : None,
	'force_stop': None,
	'created_by ': None,
	'created_date': None,
	'status': 'Building',
	'last_saved': None,
	'debug': True,
	'human_name': "Refusa Record Extractor - Restaurant SIC Codes",
	'record_tag': 'refusa-restaurant',
	'error_count': 0,
	'last_error': None,
	'extraction_last_event': None,
	'extraction_average_time': 0,
	'extraction_completion_time': 0, #Seconds
	'extraction_total_records': 0,
	'extraction_duplicate_records': None,
	'search_total_records_found': None,
	'page_current' : None,
	'page_last' : None,
	'driver' : None,
	'pending_tasks':[],
	'task': {
		'inputs': {
			'load_page': { 'url': "https://google.com" },
			'screenshot_as_base64' : { 'file_name' : None, }
		}, 
		'outputs': {
			'generate_refind_key' : None,
			'add_tag_record': None,		
			'save_record': None,
			'refind_record': None,
		}
	},
	'completed_tasks':[],
}

tjob = Job(**job)

tjob.job.status
tjob.job.error_count
tjob.job.task.inputs.load_page.url
tjob.job.human_name
tjob.job.task.inputs.screenshot_as_base64.file_name

```

![no-output](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1850981/25629890/ce7ead9e-2f30-11e7-9729-c306a65561b7.gif)

```bx = Box(a={"b": {"c": "d"}))
bx.a.b.box_heritage
```

items.title: Use property instead of to_json(),to_yaml(),etc.
items.body:
Use
```
box.json
box.yaml
box.csv


@property
def json(self):
    return {}
```

but not 
```
box.to_json()
box.to_yaml()
box.to_csv()
```
which is more pythonic. And the arguments  "filename" of to_yaml() could be instead by a method "save()". What do you think?

items.title: Auto attributes creation
items.body:
```py
>>> b = box.Box()
>>> b.o.x = 42
AttributeError: 'Box' object has no attribute 'o'
```

IMHO this should work, possibly via a subtype (`AutoBox`) or `__init__` keyword arg (`auto_attr=True`).

Another variant would be ``OpenBox`` combined with a `close()` method – i.e. allow path construction initially, but then switch to default mode (`AttributeError`) after construction.

items.title: Look into creating a DefaultBox
Look into auto conversion of keys to proper attributes
items.body:
It would be beneficial to be able to access things that have spaces in them via dot notation, by assuming that spaces are underscores.  

```
b = Box({"my dict": 1})
b.my_dict
```

This will require changes in both get and `dir`. 

Also consider adding auto snake_case to stuff that is camelCase, and potentially lower case for anything as well.
